author: p0W3RH311
body:
Hi Guys !!

there are many regular command : executable file we can run with PS but sometimes we  have conflict between executable file and PS command.

the idea is to use a symbol ex "^" before the regular command if we want use executable file for example:

```
UNIX PS> foo
function foo
UNIX PS> rm function:foo
UNIX PS> ^rm function:foo 
# ERROR 
```

comments.author: jborean93
comments.body: I feel like this just adds more work for little gain, the best thing to do is to not create a function that shadows a native command. This is usually not a problem if you follow the `Verb-Noun` syntax that is encouraged in PowerShell. If you do have a shadow then you need to explicitly invoke the command like `&(Get-Command foo -CommandType Application)`.

comments.author: p0W3RH311
comments.body:
@jborean93 

thanks,  there are many powerfull external command in nix and also in  windows and sometimes its used by the users...i know it exist `crescendo `module but its not the  same concept  used by the regular users. with this syntax:`

`PS> ^command ....etc`

its more explicit.  if the user postfix any command with "^" then the regular command its used and not any `function/cmdlet/alias/configuration/filter` is used

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: I don't really see much additional value being added here that isn't possible to do in most cases by simply affixing the file extension to the command name (e.g., `cmd.exe` vs `cmd`). Saving a few characters doesn't really make it seem worthwhile to me.

title: using regular command
